vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered in pip (all versions) because it installs the version with the highest version number, even if the user had intended to obtain a private package from a private index. This only affects use of the --extra-index-url option, and exploitation requires that the package does not already exist in the public index (and thus the attacker can put the package there with an arbitrary version number). NOTE: it has been reported that this is intended functionality and the user is responsible for using --extra-index-url securely

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: pip could download private packages from a public PyPI repository leading to code execution.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
This CVE refers to the possibility of a "dependency confusion" attack when using `pip` with the `--extra-index-url` flag. This vulnerability has been disputed by the maintainers of pip as the described behavior is intended (although potentially insecure) and as such there are no plans to fix it. 

If pip is executed with the `--extra-index-url` when using a private PyPI repository, an attacker could cause pip to download a private package (for example one named `private_package`) by adding a package with the same name (`private_package`) in the public PyPI repository. This would lead to remote code execution as pip will download the public package that could contain malicious code. This dependency confusion attack was [demonstrated in 2021 by Alex Birsan](https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610).

severityReasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
severityReasons.description: Pip maintainers, and others such as [RHEL](https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2018-20225) do not consider this a vulnerability as it is the intended behaviour

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: A malicious package can contain arbitrary code, which is by definition a severe code execution impact

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: Exploitation requires the pip client to use the `--extra-index-url` flag. The attacker must research and find the names of the "private packages" being installed by the victim, and then publish packages with the same name (but containing a malicious payload) to PyPI.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Do not use the `--extra-index-url` flag with pip and consider using version pinning for deployments.

urllib3: urllib3 vulnerable to decompression-bomb safeguard bypass when following HTTP redirects (streaming API)

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Resource exhaustion (zip bomb) in urllib3 could lead to denial of service when making requests to an untrusted HTTP server using non-default request flags
jfrogResearchInformation.details: [urllib3](https://pypi.org/project/urllib3/) is a robust and widely-adopted HTTP client library for Python, offering essential features like thread-safe connection pooling and client-side SSL/TLS verification. It provides comprehensive request handling, including file uploads, automatic retry helpers, proxy support, and decoding for various content encodings (e.g., gzip, brotli, zstd).

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: Exploitation of the vulnerability requires the user to send an HTTP request to an untrusted server with `preload_content=False` (`True` by default) and `redirect=True` (`True` by default).

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Exploitation of the vulnerability may result in the client application crashing due to resource exhaustion.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The attacker can simply return an HTTP response containing a "zip bomb" to trigger the resource exhaustion

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Users can remediate the risk by setting `redirect` to `False`. For example:

```
import urllib3

resp = urllib3.request(
    "GET",
    "https://httpbin.org/cookies/set/session/f3efe9db",
    preload_content=False,
    redirect=False
)
```

vulnerabilities.summary: urllib3: urllib3 Streaming API improperly handles highly compressed data

urllib3 is an HTTP client library for Python. urllib3's streaming API is designed for the efficient handling of large HTTP responses by reading the content in chunks, rather than loading the entire response body into memory at once. urllib3 can perform decoding or decompression based on the HTTP `Content-Encoding` header (e.g., `gzip`, `deflate`, `br`, or `zstd`). When using the streaming API, the library decompresses only the necessary bytes, enabling partial content consumption. Starting in version 1.22 and prior to version 2.6.3, for HTTP redirect responses, the library would read the entire response body to drain the connection and decompress the content unnecessarily. This decompression occurred even before any read methods were called, and configured read limits did not restrict the amount of decompressed data. As a result, there was no safeguard against decompression bombs. A malicious server could exploit this to trigger excessive resource consumption on the client. Applications and libraries are affected when they stream content from untrusted sources by setting `preload_content=False` when they do not disable redirects. Users should upgrade to at least urllib3 v2.6.3, in which the library does not decode content of redirect responses when `preload_content=False`. If upgrading is not immediately possible, disable redirects by setting `redirect=False` for requests to untrusted source.

It provides comprehensive request handling, including file uploads, automatic retry helpers, proxy support, and decoding for various content encodings (e.g., gzip, brotli, zstd).

vulnerabilities.summary: GnuPG: GnuPG: Information disclosure and potential arbitrary code execution via out-of-bounds write

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A heap buffer overwrite in GnuPG may result in arbitrary code execution when parsing maliciously crafted messages.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[GnuPG](https://www.gnupg.org/) is an implementation of the OpenPGP standard as defined by RFC4880
GnuPG is an implementation of OpenPGP in the C language that offers a variety of command lines and libraries. The native format of OpenPGP data is binary. However, it is customary to use the PGP data in a non-binary encoding called "ASCII armor", which is easier to copy and handle.

A double increment bug in the `armor_filter()` function, which is part of the ASCII-armor parsing process, results in every other byte in the buffer being uninitialized and may result in a heap buffer overwrite.

The vulnerability is exploitable when using the `gpg` command line with the `--dearmor` or `--enarmor` flags.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Exploitation of the vulnerability results in heap memory corruption, which may lead to arbitrary code execution.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: To exploit the vulnerability, a potential attacker needs to supply a maliciously crafted message that will get parsed by the `gpg` command-line tool, using the `--dearmor` or `--enarmor` flags.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: A technical write-up of the vulnerability is available, demonstrating the requirements to reach the vulnerable code path.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Users can mitigate the risk by disabling ASCII armor parsing:

1. Ensure the `gpg` command line is not used with the vulnerable `--dearmor` or `--enarmor` flags.

2. Implement a security measure to make sure an input does not contain ASCII armor before passing it into GnuPG. For example, the user can check the first few bytes of the input, and reject it if it starts with `-----`. A Python example:

```
def secure_gpg_decrypt(encrypted_data):
    header_check = encrypted_data.strip()[:5]
    
    if b"-----" in header_check:
        raise ValueError("ASCII Armor detected!")

    return "No ASCII Armor detected."

```

vulnerabilities.summary: urllib3: urllib3: Unbounded decompression chain leads to resource exhaustion

urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python. Starting in version 1.0 and prior to 2.6.0, the Streaming API improperly handles highly compressed data. urllib3's streaming API is designed for the efficient handling of large HTTP responses by reading the content in chunks, rather than loading the entire response body into memory at once. When streaming a compressed response, urllib3 can perform decoding or decompression based on the HTTP Content-Encoding header (e.g., gzip, deflate, br, or zstd). The library must read compressed data from the network and decompress it until the requested chunk size is met. Any resulting decompressed data that exceeds the requested amount is held in an internal buffer for the next read operation. The decompression logic could cause urllib3 to fully decode a small amount of highly compressed data in a single operation. This can result in excessive resource consumption (high CPU usage and massive memory allocation for the decompressed data.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Resource exhaustion in urllib3 leads to denial of service when making requests to untrusted HTTP servers due to excessive decompression during API streaming.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[urllib3](https://pypi.org/project/urllib3/) is a robust and widely-adopted HTTP client library for Python, offering essential features like thread-safe connection pooling and client-side SSL/TLS verification. It provides comprehensive request handling, including file uploads, automatic retry helpers, proxy support, and decoding for various content encodings (e.g., gzip, brotli, zstd).
The flaw was in the `ContentDecoder` classes, responsible for processing incoming compressed content during streaming. The underlying decompression library (e.g. `zlib`) was called without a length limit, meaning it would fully decompress all input data received from the network in a single operation. 

This results in the allocation of memory for all the decompressed data, even if only a small amount was requested, leading to excessive memory consumption for the decompressed data and possibly to a denial of service.

Any application using the vulnerable urllib3 client that makes an HTTP request to an untrusted server and attempts to stream or read the response body in chunks is vulnerable:

```
resp = http.request("GET", "http://malicious-server.com/bomb", preload_content=False)
chunk = resp.read(1024) 
```

The attacker crafts an HTTP response with a standard compression header (e.g. `Content-Encoding: gzip`) and a highly-compressible small payload. This leads to forced excessive allocations of memory for the decompressed data in the internal buffer, causing the client process to become unusable for other processes.

Exploitation is mainly through web crawlers, security tools, and any application that routinely processes responses from arbitrary, untrusted URLs (where the attacker can control the server) using the streaming API.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Crashing a HTTP client

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The client application must make an HTTP request to a compromised or malicious server. Exploitation focuses mainly on automated client systems such as web scrapers and applications that routinely retrieve and process data from attacker-controlled endpoints, which does not ensure a safe decompression limit and attempt to read the response body in small, controlled chunks using the streaming API (e.g. `response.stream()`)

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The server only has to respond to the client's HTTP request with a `Content-Encoding` header and a highly-compressed payload that will expand massively when decompressed by the client.

vulnerabilities.summary: urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python. Starting in version 1.24 and prior to 2.6.0, the number of links in the decompression chain was unbounded allowing a malicious server to insert a virtually unlimited number of compression steps leading to high CPU usage and massive memory allocation for the decompressed data. This vulnerability is fixed in 2.6.0.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Resource exhaustion in urllib3 leads to denial of service when making requests to untrusted HTTP servers due excessive Content-Encoding processing
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[urllib3](https://pypi.org/project/urllib3/) is a robust and widely-adopted HTTP client library for Python, offering essential features like thread-safe connection pooling and client-side SSL/TLS verification. It provides comprehensive request handling, including file uploads, automatic retry helpers, proxy support, and decoding for various content encodings (e.g., gzip, brotli, zstd).
The flaw was in the `MultiDecoder` class, responsible for processing the `Content-Encoding` header, which was missing a check on the length of this list. The unbounded number of links in the decompression chain allows a malicious server to cause unlimited number of compression steps, leading to excessive memory consumption for the decompressed data and possibly to a denial of service.

Any application using the vulnerable urllib3 client that makes an HTTP request to an untrusted server, receives the response headers and attempts to read the response body, making them vulnerable:

```
response = requests.get("http://malicious-server.com/api/data")
data = response.content
```

The attacker can crafts an HTTP response with a manipulated `Content-Encoding` header that specifies a high number of compression algorithms:

```
Content-Encoding: gzip, [... thousands more links], gzip, 
```
This leads to repeated forced allocations of memory for decompression, and causes the client to become unusable for other processes.

Exploitation is mainly through web crawlers, security tools, and any application that routinely processes responses from arbitrary, untrusted URLs (where the attacker can control the server).

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The client application must make an HTTP request to a compromised or malicious server. Exploitation focuses mainly on automated client systems such as web scrapers and applications that routinely retrieve and process data from attacker-controlled endpoints, which does not ensure a safe limited number of encodings before reading the response content.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The server only has to respond to the client's HTTP request with a `Content-Encoding` header that specifies an excessive number of compression algorithms to cause high CPU usage and possibly denial of service on the client.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Crashing a HTTP client

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Use `preload_content=False` to prevent urllib3 from automatically decompressing the entire response body:

```
resp = http.request("GET", url, preload_content=False)
```

vulnerabilities.summary: linux-pam: Incomplete fix for CVE-2025-6020

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient separation in `pam_namespace` may lead to local privilege escalation
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
This CVE was assigned due to an incomplete fix of CVE-2025-6020. The incomplete fix may only affect Red Hat distributions, and at this time no additional details are available (no upstream commits are associated with this issue). The following information is similar to CVE-2025-6020 -

The `pam_namespace` module is part of the Linux PAM (Pluggable Authentication Module) system. Its goal is to enhance user isolation by creating private mount namespaces for each user session. Within these namespaces, it can polyinstantiate certain directories (like `/tmp` or `$HOME`), giving each user or session a private version thats hidden from others. This helps prevent information leaks, symlink attacks, and other types of local privilege escalation in multi-user environments.

`pam_namespace` is designed to isolate user directories using mount namespaces. However, due to incomplete protection against symlink/race condition attacks, an unprivileged user can potentially gain root access.
The attacker must be able to launch a controlled process outside of their PAM session, by doing so they will be able to alter the paths on which `pam_namespace` is operating as root.

This can allow attackers to -
1. Launch symlink attacks on a path used by `pam_namespace` during polyinstantiation setup
2. Launch race condition attacks on the security checks in `pam_namespace`
Either of these can allow the local attacker to escalate privileges to root

This is more feasible if:
1. The system has multiple users colluding with each other or-
2. PAM services are misconfigured and do not call `pam_namespace`


Examples:

1. If two users on the same system are either colluding or both compromised, one of them can tamper with the paths used to polyinstantiate directories for the other. This is possible because each user operates within their own PAM session, which places them in a separate mount namespace. As a result, the restrictions enforced by `pam_namespace` do not apply across these namespaces, allowing one user to interf...

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
To exploit this CVE, at least one of the following prerequisites must be met:

* The system has multiple users which are colluding with each other
* At least one PAM service is misconfigured and does not call `pam_namespace` when
  creating a new PAM session

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Successful exploitation allows a weak user to elevate and run anything as root.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

If `pam_namespace` is not essential for your environment, consider disabling it - this can be done by **commenting out or deleting** the following line from every file in `/etc/pam.d` -
`session required pam_namespace.so`

If `pam_namespace` is essential in your deployment, ensure it is carefully reviewed and configured to prevent it from interacting with directories or paths that unprivileged users can control, such as user home directories or world-writable locations like `/tmp`.

libxslt: Heap Use-After-Free in libxslt caused by atype corruption in xmlAttrPtr

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Libxslt is vulnerable to a heap-use-after-free condition when the atype field in an attribute node is corrupted.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[libxslt](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxslt/-/wikis/home) is the XSLT C library developed for the GNOME project. XSLT itself is an XML language to define a transformation for XML. libxslt is based on libxml2, the XML C library developed for the GNOME project.

A heap use-after-free vulnerability in libxslt occurs when the `atype` field of an attribute node is corrupted. This field, used by libxml2 to determine whether an attribute is an `XML ID`, is improperly modified the function `xsltSetSourceNodeFlags()` sets additional flag bits not recognized by libxml2.

This issue can be triggered by crafted XSLT stylesheets that apply the `key()` function to attribute nodes within result tree fragments. When the corrupted `atype` makes an attribute incorrectly appear as an ID, libxml2 may skip necessary cleanup steps, such as calling `xmlRemoveID()` during memory deallocation.

As a result, entries in the internal ID table may continue to reference freed memory. Subsequent calls to `xmlFreeID()` can then dereference these dangling pointers, leading to crashes, heap corruption, or denial-of-service.

Since libxslt is commonly used in server-side XML processing, this could result in denial-of-service or potentially facilitate code execution under certain memory reuse conditions.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Since libxslt is commonly used in server-side XML processing, exploitation of this issue could result in denial-of-service or potentially facilitate code execution under certain memory reuse conditions.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: To exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must control the XSLT stylesheet, which is normally not user-controlled. In most likely scenarios, the attacker may be able to control the parsed XML file input, but that alone is insufficient to trigger the vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary: python: cpython: Arbitrary writes via tarfile realpath overflow

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A filter bypass in the tarfile Python module may lead to arbitrary file overwrite when extracting a crafted tar archive using a nondefault extraction filter
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Python](https://www.python.org/) is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity, readability, and versatility.
The Python standard library is a collection of modules and packages that are part of the Python distribution by default and provides a wide range of functionality for common tasks, such as working with data structures, file I/O, networking, and more.
The [`tarfile`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/tarfile.html# ) module enables reading and writing tar archives, including those compressed with gzip, bz2, and lzma. 

An arbitrary write was found when using the `tarfile` module to extract untrusted tar archives when `TarFile.extractall()` or `TarFile.extract()` is used with the `filter` parameter set to a non-default value of `data` or `tar`.
**Note that on Python 3.14 (pre-release version) the default value of `filter` is vulnerable (`data`)**

The vulnerability occurs in the internal function `makelink`, which is being called by `_extract_member` and does not get the filter passed to it 

When a user attempts to extract an untrusted tar file that is a symbolic link, the file is passed to the function without being filtered, and the file to be extracted is not filtered. This vulnerability may lead to an arbitrary write for the attacker.

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: The user needs to extract a crafted tar archive

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
The vulnerability is exploited when `TarFile.extractall()` or `TarFile.extract()` is used on a crafted tar archive, with the `filter` parameter set to a non-default value of `data` or `tar`.
**Note that on Python 3.14 (pre-release version) the default value of `filter` is vulnerable (`data`)**

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The attacker can simply create a tar archive with symbolic links that will be served to the victim user

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

When using  `TarFile.extractall()` or `TarFile.extract()`, deny any tar archive that contains symbolic links with the `..` characters, for example -
```py
import pathlib

# Avoid insecure segments in link names.
# 'tar' is a tarfile open for reading.
for member in tar.getmembers():
    if member.linkname and '..' in pathlib.Path(member.linkname).parts:
        raise OSError("Tarfile with insecure segment ('..') in linkname")

# Now safe to extract members with the data filter.
tar.extractall(filter="data")
```

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient separation in `pam_namespace` may lead to local privilege escalation
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The `pam_namespace` module is part of the Linux PAM (Pluggable Authentication Module) system. Its goal is to enhance user isolation by creating private mount namespaces for each user session. Within these namespaces, it can polyinstantiate certain directories (like `/tmp` or `$HOME`), giving each user or session a private version thats hidden from others. This helps prevent information leaks, symlink attacks, and other types of local privilege escalation in multi-user environments.

`pam_namespace` is designed to isolate user directories using mount namespaces. However, due to incomplete protection against symlink/race condition attacks, an unprivileged user can potentially gain root access.
The attacker must be able to launch a controlled process outside of their PAM session, by doing so they will be able to alter the paths on which `pam_namespace` is operating as root.

This can allow attackers to -
1. Launch symlink attacks on a path used by `pam_namespace` during polyinstantiation setup
2. Launch race condition attacks on the security checks in `pam_namespace`
Either of these can allow the local attacker to escalate privileges to root

This is more feasible if:
1. The system has multiple users colluding with each other or-
2. PAM services are misconfigured and do not call `pam_namespace`


Examples:

1. If two users on the same system are either colluding or both compromised, one of them can tamper with the paths used to polyinstantiate directories for the other. This is possible because each user operates within their own PAM session, which places them in a separate mount namespace. As a result, the restrictions enforced by `pam_namespace` do not apply across these namespaces, allowing one user to interfere with the other's environment.

2. If a PAM service is misconfigured and fails to invoke `pam_namespace` during the creation of a new PAM session, it opens up a potential security gap. This kind of misconfiguration is not uncommon, as some packages provide PAM service files that omit...

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
To exploit this CVE, at least one of the following prerequisites must be met:

* The system has multiple users which are colluding with each other
* At least one PAM service is misconfigured and does not call `pam_namespace` when
  creating a new PAM session

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Successful exploitation allows a weak user to elevate and run anything as root.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

If `pam_namespace` is not essential for your environment, consider disabling it - this can be done by **commenting out or deleting** the following line from every file in `/etc/pam.d` -
`session required pam_namespace.so`

If `pam_namespace` is essential in your deployment, ensure it is carefully reviewed and configured to prevent it from interacting with directories or paths that unprivileged users can control, such as user home directories or world-writable locations like `/tmp`.

vulnerabilities.summary: setuptools is a package that allows users to download, build, install, upgrade, and uninstall Python packages. A path traversal vulnerability in `PackageIndex` is present in setuptools prior to version 78.1.1. An attacker would be allowed to write files to arbitrary locations on the filesystem with the permissions of the process running the Python code, which could escalate to remote code execution depending on the context. Version 78.1.1 fixes the issue.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A path traversal in Python's Setuptools may lead to arbitrary file overwrite by providing a crafted package URL.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Setuptools](https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/) is a fully-featured, actively-maintained, and stable library designed to facilitate packaging Python projects.

A path traversal vulnerability in `PackageIndex` is present in setuptools prior to version 78.1.1. An attacker would be allowed to write files to arbitrary locations on the filesystem with the permissions of the process running the Python code, which could escalate to remote code execution depending on the context.

The `PackageIndex` module within the library provides a convenient way to interact with package index servers, but is vulnerable to arbitrary file overwrite through its download functions. These download functions are utilized in various parts of the setuptools library, specifically for downloading packages from provided URLs on package index servers. These URLs can be provided by users or automatically retrieved (by setuptools) from the HTML pages of a Package index server like PyPi or a custom one.

The `_download_url` function in `PackageIndex` is responsible for setting the downloaded filename. It gets as arguments the tmp directory path `tmpdir` and the URL `url` of the file to be downloaded into it. The file's`name` is then extracted from the `url` using the `egg_info_for_url` function, without sufficient sanitization.

The absolute path of the file is set using:

`filename = os.path.join(tmpdir, name)`

It attempts to construct a full path by concatenating `name` to `tmpdir`. However, `os.path.join()` discards the first argument `tmpdir` in case that `name` begins with a slash or a drive letter.
If an attacker can supply a crafted URL such as the following, it might write to a sensitive location:

`<server_domain_name>//home/user/.ssh/authorized_keys`

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A stack buffer overflow in libxml2 may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted XML document with specific parser arguments.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is a software library for parsing XML documents.
Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.
An `XML Document Type Definition` is a formal expression (in XML) that defines an XML document's structure, legal elements, and attributes.

It was discovered that when `libxml2` is parsing XML DTD attributes list, a stack overflow can occur. This may lead to denial of service.

To exploit this, an attacker has to send a maliciously crafted XML file to a victim service that processes XML with libxml2 (ex. by using `xmlReadFile` or `xmlParseFile`).

vulnerabilities.summary: openssl: RFC7250 handshakes with unauthenticated servers don't abort as expected

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in OpenSSL may allow network attackers to perform man-in-the-middle attacks when raw public keys are used.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
OpenSSL is an open-source cryptographic library and toolset that provides a wide range of protocol supported and functions for secure communication, data encryption, digital certificates, and other cryptographic operations, widely used in various software applications and systems.
In OpenSSL, the `SSL_VERIFY_PEER` verification mode is used to enforce the verification of the remote server's SSL/TLS certificate during the handshake process of a secure connection. When this mode is set, the client (or server, depending on the context) will check the validity of the presented certificate against a criteria set.

Raw public keys (RPK) are a cryptographic method in public key infrastructure (PKI) that represent a public key without a digital certificate. Unlike certificates, which include extra details like identity and expiration, raw public keys are simpler and more efficient, making them ideal for resource-limited environments.

In OpenSSL, connections made using TLS and DTLS with RPKs may allow attackers to man-in-the-middle if clients fail to recognize a failure in server authentication. The problem only emerges when TLS clients deliberately activate RPK usage for the server, which in turn chooses to transmit an RPK instead of an X.509 certificate chain. The clients that are impacted are those that expect the handshake to fail if the servers RPK does not align with one of the anticipated public keys, as determined by setting the verification mode to `SSL_VERIFY_PEER`.

Clients that enable server-side RPKs can still find out that RPK verification failed by calling the `SSL_get_verify_result()` function. If this check is made right after the handshake, clients can abort the communication in the proper cases and therefore will not be vulnerable.

Note: By default, RPKs are turned off in both TLS clients and servers.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Data leakage.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: Raw Public Keys are disabled by default in both TLS clients and TLS servers, which is mandatory to exploit this CVE.

severityReasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to intercept the communication between the client and the server using a man-in-the-middle attack.

vulnerabilities.summary: pam: Improper Hostname Interpretation in pam_access Leads to Access Control Bypass

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in PAM may lead to authentication bypass by remote attackers when specific access.conf rules are defined.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
The vulnerability only poses a risk in environments that rely on PAM's `access.conf` for local access control and contain vulnerable configurations.
A vulnerable configuration is one that uses strings which are not any of the following -
1. Hostnames (anything with a dot) 
2. ALL/LOCAL/localhost/NONE/EXCEPT 
3. IPv4 addresses or IPv6 addresses.

Example vulnerable configuration -
```
+:root:cron crond :0 tty1 tty2 tty3 tty4 tty5 tty6
```

Example non-vulnerable configuration -
```
+:root:LOCAL
```

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description:
Exploitation of this vulnerability requires either that the attacker use DNS spoofing to fake their hostname, or that the attacker and the victim be in the same LAN. 
In addition, the attacker has to be able to log in to the relevant user (e.g. with credentials).
The vulnerability only poses a risk in environments that rely on PAM's `access.conf` for local access control.

severityReasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
severityReasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability depends on the permissions given to the relevant user.

vulnerabilities.summary: pypa/setuptools: Remote code execution via download functions in the package_index module in pypa/setuptools

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient input validation in Python's Setuptools may lead to remote code execution by providing a crafted package URL.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Setuptools](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools) is a library that lets developers easily build and distribute Python packages.

A vulnerability has been discovered in the function `_download_vcs()` in Setuptools. This function is responsible for downloading packages from a VCS (a Version Control System - `git` or `hg`). It is used, for example, by `PackageIndex.download()`. It has been found that `_download_vcs()` is prone to command injection, because it executes the VCS commands using `os.system()` like this:

`os.system(f"{vcs} clone --quiet {url} {filename}")`

The `url` variable is provided as an input to the function, and defines the URL from which the package should be downloaded. Thus, an attacker who controls this URL can escape the `{vcs}` command and inject his own shell commands.

This vulnerability is only applicable if an attacker controls a URL that is provided as a package to download. This URL can be provided in several ways: through `setup.py`, through the CLI (`python setup.py easy_install <URL>`), through Python functions such as `PackageIndex.download()`, or through a custom package index server (which is configured in `setup.cfg`).

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description:
The attacker must be able to control a URL that is provided as a package to download or convince the victim to download the malicious package.
Another scenario would be an attacker that compromises a package index server, in which case the a package content can already be modified to execute code without needing this vulnerability.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is RCE and full system compromise.

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: In most cases, exploiting the vulnerability will require user interaction (ex. running pip).

vulnerabilities.summary: freeradius: forgery attack

A vulnerability was identified in the kjd/idna library, specifically within the `idna.encode()` function, affecting version 3.6. The issue arises from the function's handling of crafted input strings, which can lead to quadratic complexity and consequently, a denial of service condition. This vulnerability is triggered by a crafted input that causes the `idna.encode()` function to process the input with considerable computational load, significantly increasing the processing time in a quadratic manner relative to the input size.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in idna may lead to denial of service when encoding crafted input.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[idna](https://github.com/kjd/idna) is a library used for encoding and decoding domain names according to the [IDNA](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5891) standard. This standard specifies how the conversion between domain names written in non-ASCII characters and their ASCII-based representation should be performed.

A vulnerability has been discovered in the function `valid_contextj()` in idna, which is responsible for validating certain rules that are related to [CONTEXTJ characters](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#autoid-32) ([`\u200c`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#appendix-A.1) and [`\u200d`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#appendix-A.2)). Specifically, the character `\u200c` requires a certain pattern to exist before and after the character. It has been discovered that the code in `valid_contextj()` keeps looking for the pattern even after it can no longer exist. This can lead to a denial of service attack, when the function is supplied with a very long input that contains a lot of `\u200c`.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability has a simple published exploit.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The impact of the vulnerability is a remote denial of service that requires no user interaction or per-target specific research.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: An attacker needs to find input that propagates to the vulnerable function `idna.encode()`.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

There are two ways to mitigate this:
By limiting the input to 253 characters or not allowing for the character `\u200c` to exist in the input to the vulnerable function.

vulnerabilities.summary: python: Path traversal on tempfile.TemporaryDirectory

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A race condition in Python's built-in tempfile module may allow local attackers to modify permissions of protected files by abusing symbolic links (unspecified impact).
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[tempfile](https://docs.python.org/3/library/tempfile.html) is a Python module responsible for the creation of temporary files and directories.

The `_rmtree()` function is used to recursively delete a temporary folder and all the files within it. Mishandling of cases where files within the temporary folder use symlinks to sensitive information located outside of the folder could lead to the changing of permissions of the sensitive files. 

When `_rmtree()` attempts to remove a file without the permissions to do so, an internal call to `resetperms()` is triggered. Due to the mishandling of cases where files have symlinks, `resetperms()` changes the permissions of the sensitive file into `0o700`, granting the owner full read and write permissions.

To exploit the vulnerability, a potential attacker must have the ability to create symlinks inside the temporary directory before `_rmtree()` is called.

The vulnerability has an unspecified impact, since granting `0o700` permissions to a file, only affects the file's owner. However - the file's owner is free to call `chmod` to change the permissions arbitrarily, thus there is no security impact.

severityReasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
severityReasons.description: To exploit the vulnerability, the attacker must have access to the temporary directory as it is created and make a symlink to the target file before the temporary folder is deleted.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability has an unspecified impact, since granting `0o700` permissions to a file, only affects the file's owner. However - the file's owner is free to call `chmod` to change the permissions arbitrarily, thus there is no security impact.

vulnerabilities.summary: glibc: Out of bounds write in iconv may lead to remote code execution

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An out-of-bound write vulnerability in Glibc can lead to denial of service when using a specific character set.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Glibc](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/) is a library that provides core libraries with API functions.

`ISO-2022-CN` is a 7-bit Chinese character encoding that supports simplified and traditional Chinese characters. `ISO-2022-CN-EXT` is an extension of `ISO-2022-CN` that supports other GB character sets.

The vulnerability was introduced in the GNU C Library versions 2.39 in the `iconv()` function.
Attackers can use the out-of-bounds write vulnerability by overflowing the buffer passed to the `iconv()` function and potentially overwriting the neighboring variables or crashing the application.
`SS2designation` and `SS3designation` do not perform the necessary boundary checks, allowing attackers to overflow of 1, 2, or 3 bytes with fixed values by converting the following strings to the `ISO-2022-CN-EXT` character set: '$+I', '$+J', '$+K', '$+L', '$+M', or '$*H'.

The researcher who found the vulnerability mentioned that it is not likely to be exploited in most libraries and programs except for PHP which was found to be applicable.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The researcher who found the vulnerability mentioned that it is not likely to be exploited in most libraries and programs except for PHP which was found to be applicable.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: This issue can lead to a Denial of Service.

severityReasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability was discussed at the OffensiveCon conference.

vulnerabilities.summary: urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python. urllib3 doesn't treat the `Cookie` HTTP header special or provide any helpers for managing cookies over HTTP, that is the responsibility of the user. However, it is possible for a user to specify a `Cookie` header and unknowingly leak information via HTTP redirects to a different origin if that user doesn't disable redirects explicitly. This issue has been patched in urllib3 version 1.26.17 or 2.0.5.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in urlib3 may lead to data leakage when handling HTTP redirects with a cookie header.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
In order for the vulnerability to be present, all of the following conditions are required:
1. HTTP redirects should not be disabled, which is the default.
2. HTTPS is not used, or the origin server is allowed to redirect to a malicious origin.
3. Sensitive cookies should be included in the request - through the 'Cookies' header.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: In order to exploit the vulnerability, the attacker has to redirect the user and receive the subsequent request containing the cookies.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability may leak the user's session cookies.

glib: Integer overflow in in g_escape_uri_string()

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Heap buffer overflow in glib may lead to remote code execution when converting large crafted filenames to URIs
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Glib](https://docs.gtk.org/glib/) is the low-level core library that forms the basis for projects such as GTK and GNOME. It provides data structure handling for C, portability wrappers, and interfaces for such runtime functionality as an event loop, threads, dynamic loading, and an object system.
The vulnerability can be triggered when arbitrary input is supplied to the `g_filename_to_uri ` exported function (the input propagates to the vulnerable `g_escape_file_uri` private function).

The `g_escape_uri_string` function of `glib/gconvert.c`, which is responsible for escaping characters in a URI is vulnerable to integer overflow. The function calculates the necessary buffer size for the escaped string using the formula `p - string + unacceptable * 2 + 1`. However, because the variable `unacceptable` (which counts characters needing escaping) was defined as a signed integer, and the input string can be extremely large, this calculation can result in an integer overflow or wraparound.

When this overflow occurs, the `g_malloc` function allocates a heap buffer that is significantly smaller than required for the resulting data. As the function proceeds to write the escaped output into this undersized buffer, it writes past the allocated boundary, causing a heap-based buffer overflow. This CVE could potentially lead to arbitrary code execution.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: Published exploit demonstrates denial of service

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability requires the application to accept and process a single string input larger than 2GB (to trigger the overflow) with the `g_filename_to_uri` function, which is a rare configuration and unlikely to be allowed in remote attack scenarios.

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: While a denial of service PoC was published, the vulnerability was not proven to be able to lead to arbitrary code execution. However, heap overflow vulnerabilities are likely to be able to lead to arbitrary code execution.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Exploitation could theoretically lead to remote code execution

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A buffer overflow vulnerability in OpenSSL may result in denial of service and potential remote code execution when decrypting a maliciously crafted encrypted CMS message.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
OpenSSL is an open-source cryptographic library and toolset that provides a wide range of protocol supported and functions for secure communication, data encryption, digital certificates, and other cryptographic operations, widely used in various software applications and systems.
A miscalculation in `kek_unwrap_key()`, which is part of the decryption process for `password-protected CMS` (Cryptographic Message Syntax), may result in reading more data than is available in the input buffer, leading to an out-of-bounds read of up to 8 bytes. Moreover, the miscalculation may allow an out-of-bounds write of up to 4 bytes, which can lead to memory corruption and a denial-of-service.

A maliciously crafted CRM should answer BOTH of the following conditions to trigger the vulnerability:

1. `tmp[0] <= inline + 4`
2. `tmp[0] > inline`

Where `tmp[0]` is the key length as represented by the first byte of the ciphertext, and `inline` is the total length of the input ciphertext.

The vulnerable functions include functions that trigger the CRM decryption process, such as `CMS_verify`, `CRM_decrypt`, `CMS_decrypt_set1_password`, and more.

Other than API, the vulnerability can also be triggered via the OpenSSL CLI, when using the `cms` tool with a malicious encrypted CMS message, for example -
`openssl cms -decrypt -in encrypted.cms -out decrypted.txt -inkey private.pem`

Note that the vulnerability only affects the decryption process of password-encrypted CMS. Decryption of non-password-protected CMS is safe.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The exploitation of the vulnerability requires the victim to decrypt a password-encrypted CMS, either using API (`CMS_verify`, `CRM_decrypt`, `CMS_decrypt_set1_password` etc.) or interactively

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: Although arbitrary code execution is potentially possible (due to the 4-byte OOB write), no exploit nor technical advisory proved it is achievable in this case.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The probability for exploitation is unlikely since password based encryption support in CMS messages is very rarely used.

vulnerabilities.summary:
When extracting a tar archive pip may not check symbolic links point into the extraction directory if the tarfile module doesn't implement PEP 706.
Note that upgrading pip to a "fixed" version for this vulnerability doesn't fix all known vulnerabilities that are remediated by using a Python version that implements PEP 706.

Note that this is a vulnerability in pip's fallback implementation of tar extraction for Python versions that don't implement PEP 706
and therefore are not secure to all vulnerabilities in the Python 'tarfile' module. If you're using a Python version that implements PEP 706
then pip doesn't use the "vulnerable" fallback code.

Mitigations include upgrading to a version of pip that includes the fix, upgrading to a Python version that implements PEP 706 (Python >=3.9.17, >=3.10.12, >=3.11.4, or >=3.12),
applying the linked patch, or inspecting source distributions (sdists) before installation as is already a best-practice.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A path traversal vulnerability in pip leads to arbitrary file writes when installing crafted pip packages.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[pip](https://pypi.org/project/pip/) is the package installer for Python. You can use pip to install packages from the Python Package Index and other indexes.
As part of a pip package installation, when extracting a source distribution (sdist), there is no check in place to make sure that paths of the archived files are not relative paths or don't contain [symbolic links](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_link) to files outside of the scope of the archive. This allows a potential attacker to use a crafted sdist archive to write/overwrite their files in unauthorized locations.

This vulnerability exists because pip has a fallback logic for older Python versions that don't implement PEP 706.
PEP 706 introduced a secure data filter (`tarfile.data_filter`) into Python's standard library tarfile module, which inherently prevents path traversal attacks by rejecting unsafe members during extraction.

This means that the following Python versions (that implement PEP 706) are not vulnerable:

* Python 3.9.17 or later
* Python 3.10.12 or later
* Python 3.11.4 or later
* Python 3.12 or later

The vulnerability, in practice, does not have a security impact. For the vulnerability to be exploited, the victim user has to install a crafted pip package. However - pip packages natively support code execution in installation time, regardless of any vulnerability.

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: To successfully exploit this CVE, the user needs to run `pip install` with a malicious package as input.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability, in practice, does not have a security impact. For the vulnerability to be exploited, the victim user has to install a crafted pip package. However - pip packages natively support code execution in installation time, regardless of any vulnerability. Therefore, the vulnerability does not add any security impact to the already dangerous scenario of installing crafted pip packages.

vulnerabilities.summary: libxslt: libxml2: Inifinite recursion at exsltDynMapFunction function in libexslt/dynamic.c
cpython: Cpython infinite loop when parsing a tarfile

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Infinite loop in Python tarfile leads to denial of service when opening a crafted tar file.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
Python applications that use the [tarfile](https://docs.python.org/3/library/tarfile.html) built-in library are susceptible to a denial of service, since opening a crafted tar file using `tarfile.open` will trigger an infinite loop.

The `nti()` internal function is responsible for the conversion of number fields in the tar file's metadata to a Python number. The function handles two different number encoding formats: traditional octal format and binary. In cases where the `size field` starts with octal `0o377` (0xFF) and ends with a `0`, `nti()` will convert the number field into a negative number.

An oversight in the `_block()` function allows a negative number to be used to calculate the offset of the next block to be processed in the tarfile, which triggers a `StreamError` exception with the `seeking backward is not allowed` error raised.

The official disclosure of the vulnerability suggests that parsing a maliciously crafted tar file could lead to a "deadlock" and an infinite loop due to calculated negative offsets.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: To exploit the vulnerability, a potential attacker would need to make the victim Python code open a crafted tar file.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: An exploit demonstrating the vulnerability is available online.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

The vulnerability can be mitigated by applying the following patch after importing the `tarfile` module`:

```
import tarfile

def _block_patched(self, count):
    if count < 0:
        raise tarfile.InvalidHeaderError("invalid offset")
    return _block_patched._orig_block(self, count)

_block_patched._orig_block = tarfile.TarInfo._block
tarfile.TarInfo._block = _block_patched
```

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A double-free vulnerability in GnuTLS results in denial of service and possible memory corruption when parsing an invalid or malformed type-id object identifier.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[GnuTLS](https://gnutls.org/) is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS, and DTLS protocols and technologies around them. It provides a simple C language application programming interface (API) to access the secure communications protocols, as well as APIs to parse and write X.509, PKCS #12, and other required structures.

The `gnutls_x509_ext_export_subject_alt_names()` function is used to convert a GnuTLS `Subject Alternative Names (SAN)` into a `DER-encoded X.509 certificate extension`. 

It was found that the internal `_gnutls_write_new_othername()` function used to write an `otherName` entry into an `ASN.1` structure may trigger a double free vulnerability when failing to write the `type-id` object identifier to the `ASN.1` structure. In cases where `asn1_write_value(ext, name2, oid, 1)` returns any error code other than `ASN1_SUCCESS`, the ASN.1 structure is deleted via `asn1_delete_structure(&ext)` and the memory associated with the `ASN.1` structure is freed. 

The vulnerability can be triggered when GnuTLS users call any of the following GnuTLS APIs and pass a user-supplied `oid` argument to them - 

* `gnutls_x509_ext_export_subject_alt_names`
* `gnutls_x509_crt_set_subject_alt_othername`
* `gnutls_x509_crq_set_subject_alt_othername`
* `gnutls_x509_crt_set_issuer_alt_othername`

However, when `_gnutls_write_new_othername()` fail to write the `otherName` entry into an `ASN.1` structure, the parent function (`gnutls_x509_ext_export_subject_alt_names()`) will attempt to do a cleanup, which will trigger `asn1_delete_structure()` on the same `ASN.1` structure, which will lead to a double free, resulting in a denial of service.

* `gnutls_x509_ext_export_subject_alt_names`

cpython: Tarfile extracts filtered members when errorlevel=0

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A filter bypass in `tarfile` may lead to unwanted members being extracted from a crafted tar archive when using a filter and a non-default error level
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Python](https://www.python.org/) is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity, readability, and versatility.
The Python standard library is a collection of modules and packages that are part of the Python distribution by default and provides a wide range of functionality for common tasks, such as working with data structures, file I/O, networking, and more.
The [`tarfile`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/tarfile.html# ) module enables reading and writing tar archives, including those compressed with gzip, bz2, and lzma. 

The `TarFile` object provides an interface to a tar archive. 

During `TarFile.extract()` or `TarFile.extractall()` with `TarFile.errorlevel` set to the non-default value of `0`, a debugging message will be logged when the defined `filter` function fails, but the unsafe member will still be extracted.

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: Requires a user to extract a crafted tar archive

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability is exploitable only when `extract` or `extractall` are called with a custom `filter` argument and `Tarfile.errorlevel` set to a non-default value of `0`.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The attacker can simply create any crafted tar archive and all files will be extracted regardless of the filter defined by the victim user

setuptools: Path Traversal Vulnerability in setuptools PackageIndex

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A path traversal in Python's Setuptools may lead to arbitrary file overwrite by providing a crafted package URL.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Setuptools](https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/) is a fully-featured, actively-maintained, and stable library designed to facilitate packaging Python projects.

A path traversal vulnerability in `PackageIndex` is present in setuptools prior to version 78.1.1. An attacker would be allowed to write files to arbitrary locations on the filesystem with the permissions of the process running the Python code, which could escalate to remote code execution depending on the context.

The `PackageIndex` module within the library provides a convenient way to interact with package index servers, but is vulnerable to arbitrary file overwrite through its download functions. These download functions are utilized in various parts of the setuptools library, specifically for downloading packages from provided URLs on package index servers. These URLs can be provided by users or automatically retrieved (by setuptools) from the HTML pages of a Package index server like PyPi or a custom one.

The `_download_url` function in `PackageIndex` is responsible for setting the downloaded filename. It gets as arguments the tmp directory path `tmpdir` and the URL `url` of the file to be downloaded into it. The file's`name` is then extracted from the `url` using the `egg_info_for_url` function, without sufficient sanitization.

The absolute path of the file is set using:

`filename = os.path.join(tmpdir, name)`

It attempts to construct a full path by concatenating `name` to `tmpdir`. However, `os.path.join()` discards the first argument `tmpdir` in case that `name` begins with a slash or a drive letter.
If an attacker can supply a crafted URL such as the following, it might write to a sensitive location:

`<server_domain_name>//home/user/.ssh/authorized_keys`

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: In most cases, exploiting the vulnerability will require user interaction (ex. running pip).

severityReasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
severityReasons.description: A detailed technical write-up has been published regarding the issue.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: A potential attacker can write and overwrite arbitrary files on the user's filesystem.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description:
The attacker must be able to control a URL that is provided as a package to download or convince the victim to download a package using the malicious URL.
Another scenario would be an attacker that compromises a package index server, in which case the a package content can already be modified to execute code without needing this vulnerability.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An out-of-bounds read in libxml2 may lead to a denial of service when validating a document against an XML schema.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is an XML C parser developed for the GNOME Project.

It was discovered that insufficient checking of the `bind -> nbNodes` field in the `xmlSchemaIDCFillNodeTables()` function may result in an out-of-bound read, which in turn may lead to denial of service.

Attackers can trigger the exploit by having a specially crafted .xsd file (XML schema definition file) validated against an XML schema by one of the standard APIs, such as `xmlSchemaValidateOneElement()`, `xmlSchemaValidateFile()`, etc.

A public [proof of concept](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/issues/890) exploit exists, which demonstrates denial of service.

libxml2: Out-of-Bounds Read in libxml2

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An out-of-bounds read in libxml2 may lead to a denial of service when parsing XML via the python api.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is a software library for parsing XML documents. Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.

It was discovered that a miscalculation of the memory to be allocated in `xmlPythonFileRead()` and `xmlPythonFileReadRaw()` can lead to a denial-of-service attack. This is caused by Python converting text to UTF-8 bytes, causing memory allocation of up to 4 times the buffer size, resulting in a buffer overflow.

This vulnerability only affects the parsing of encoded characters via text streams using libxml's Python binding and does not affect binary streams. The official Python binding for libxml2, `lxml`, cannot be exploited as it does not allow the parsing of encoded characters in a text stream. Exploitation may be possible when manually setting libxml2 as the parser for XML processing in Python modules, which does not restrict the vulnerable encoded characters from being parsed.

vulnerabilities.summary: libexpat: expat: Improper Restriction of XML Entity Expansion Depth in libexpat

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in libexpat may lead to denial of service when parsing a crafted XML document.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Expat](https://libexpat.github.io/) is a stream-oriented XML parser written in C.

When parsing an XML document, it is required to map tags into entities that represent data items and can be used throughout the document. 

It has been discovered that entity resolution and substitution were implemented via the recursive function `processInternalEntity()` without adequate depth limitations for all relevant cases. This may lead to the exhaustion of the stack, resulting in a denial of service. 

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be able to parse their crafted XML using `XML_ParseBuffer()` or `XML_Parse()`.

vulnerabilities.summary: glibc: buffer overflow in the GNU C Library's assert()

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An uncontrolled global buffer overflow in glibc's assert() function may lead to local privilege escalation under rare conditions.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Glib](https://docs.gtk.org/glib/) is the low-level core library that forms the basis for projects such as GTK and GNOME. It provides data structure handling for C, portability wrappers, and interfaces for such runtime functionality as an event loop, threads, dynamic loading, and an object system.
When `assert()` fails, it is supposed to generate an error message, but it was discovered to fail to allocate enough memory for the entire message string. This causes a global buffer overflow when the program name is copied into the buffer. 

This flaw exists because the `__assert_fail_base()` function incorrectly calculates the buffer size needed to store the error message. The vulnerability is tied to the program name string and can result in an overflow, depending on the length of the string and memory alignment.

To exploit this bug for code execution, the attacker must have local access to a system and find a `setuid` program that has a separate bug causing an assertion failure, which is highly unlikely but possible. In addition, the overflown bytes are not controlled by the attacker and at most would case a 4-byte overwrite. These conditions make exploitation extremely unlikely.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: To exploit this bug for code execution, the attacker must have local access to a system and find a `setuid` program that has a separate bug causing an assertion failure, which is highly unlikely but possible. In addition, the overflown bytes are not controlled by the attacker and at most would case a 4-byte overwrite. These conditions make exploitation extremely unlikely.

severityReasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
severityReasons.description: The bug is only feasibly exploitable by local attackers, since they would need to send bad input to a SUID program to make it crash. In addition, the SUID program name must be aligned with the system's page size in order to cause a 4-byte overwrite.

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: While a technical analysis is provided, no exploit was given and was in fact said to be mostly theoretical, due to the very unlikely conditions of exploitation.

jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Glib](https://docs.gtk.org/glib/) is the low-level core library that forms the basis for projects such as GTK and GNOME. It provides data structure handling for C, portability wrappers, and interfaces for such runtime functionality as an event loop, threads, dynamic loading, and an object system.
When `assert()` fails, it is supposed to generate an error message, but it was discovered to fail to allocate enough memory for the entire message string. This causes a global buffer overflow when the program name is copied into the buffer. 

This flaw exists because the `__assert_fail_base()` function incorrectly calculates the buffer size needed to store the error message. The vulnerability is tied to the program name string and can result in an overflow, depending on the length of the string and memory alignment.

To exploit this bug for code execution, the attacker must have local access to a system and find a `setuid` program that has a separate bug causing an assertion failure, which is highly unlikely but possible. In addition, the overflown bytes are not controlled by the attacker and at most would case a 4-byte overwrite. These conditions make exploitation extremely unlikely.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: To exploit this bug for code execution, the attacker must have local access to a system and find a `setuid` program that has a separate bug causing an assertion failure, which is highly unlikely but possible. In addition, the overflown bytes are not controlled by the attacker and at most would case a 4-byte overwrite. These conditions make exploitation extremely unlikely.

severityReasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
severityReasons.description: The bug is only feasibly exploitable by local attackers, since they would need to send bad input to a SUID program to make it crash. In addition, the SUID program name must be aligned with the system's page size in order to cause a 4-byte overwrite.

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: While a technical analysis is provided, no exploit was given and was in fact said to be mostly theoretical, due to the very unlikely conditions of exploitation.

python: Virtual environment (venv) activation scripts don't quote paths

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Missing input validations in Python's venv module may lead to remote code execution when activating a virtual environment
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The Python virtual environment module, commonly referred to as venv, is a tool that enables users to create isolated environments for their Python projects. This isolation allows developers to manage dependencies for different projects separately, avoiding conflicts between packages and versions. By creating a virtual environment, you can install specific libraries and frameworks without affecting the global Python installation or other projects.

Python's virtual environment module is vulnerable to command injection through its activation script due to missing input validation, specifically missing quotes. 
When a `venv` is created, the `VIRTUAL_ENV` variable in the activation script can be replaced with the directory name for example. If the directory name is a command with quotes such as `"';uname -a;':"` the activation script will contain the following command: `VIRTUAL_ENV='/my_dir/';uname -a;':'` which will execute the command `uname -a`. 

It's important to note that the virtual environment must be created and activated locally, either directly through a social engineering attack or as part of an existing automation (for example, a pipeline script).

severityReasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
severityReasons.description: Depending on the amount of control the attacker has over the directory name and the privileges of the program creating the venv, the impact could range from very small to relatively dangerous.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: The GitHub issue contains a proof-of-concept.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: An attacker must convince the user to change a directory name, or use another vulnerability in order to change a directory name. If the attacker has at least partial control over a path that automatically activates and initializes a venv, it could also lead to downstream attack vectors.
