vulnerabilities.summary: libexpat: Negative Length Parsing Vulnerability in libexpat

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Heap buffer overflow in Expat leads to possible remote code execution when accepting negative buffer sizes in XML_ParseBuffer
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Expat](https://libexpat.github.io/) is a stream-oriented XML parser written in C.

It has been discovered that `XML_ParseBuffer()` in Expat before 2.6.3 doesn't validate whether its `len` argument is positive. This argument specifies the length of the XML document that should be parsed by the function. By passing a negative length to `XML_ParseBuffer()`, an attacker can cause incorrect parsing of the XML document, which might lead to memory corruption. Although currently unproven, this might lead to remote code execution.

In order to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be able to control the `len` parameter which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer()`. This is highly unlikely, since the developer would usually supply the length of the XML document by themselves (for example by using `stat` or `XML_GetBuffer` ).

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is denial of service and potentially more severe outcomes such as RCE.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to control the `len` which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer`. This is highly unlikely, since most commonly the developer would check the length of the XML document by themselves, or pass the `len` returned to them by `XML_GetBuffer`.

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

This vulnerability can be mitigated by validating that the `len` which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer()` is not negative.

vulnerabilities.summary: python: cpython: Iterating over a malicious ZIP file may lead to Denial of Service

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient input validation in CPython's Zipfile module may lead to denial of service while handling archives with crafted filenames.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Zipfile](https://docs.python.org/3/library/zipfile.html) is a CPython module used for handling ZIP archives. It provides tools to create, read, write, append, and list a ZIP file.

It has been discovered that the Zipfile module is vulnerable to DoS through its `_ancestry()` function. This function is responsible for generating all elements of a given path (e.g. `['b/d/f', 'b/d', 'b']` for the path `b/d/f/`). By supplying an input that starts with `//`, an attacker can cause the function to enter an infinite loop, which may lead to denial of service. 
An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability only if the `ZipFile` class is used on a user-controlled file, and if its instance was passed to the `Path` class constructor.

For example, the following code is vulnerable:
```
zf = zipfile.ZipFile("./user-file.zip", "r")
p = zipfile.Path(zf)
zf.extractall("./mydirectory") # DoS
```
By supplying a ZIP archive with a file `//myfile`, an attacker can cause this code to enter an infinite loop.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability can be exploited by providing a simple crafted input to certain functions. It also has a published PoC.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to upload a zip file which will be parsed by the `ZipFile` class and also used by the `Path` class. Alternatively, the attacker must be able to control a filename passed to `writestr` (when creating a new zip archive)

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

There are two ways in which the vulnerability can be exploited, and thus there are two ways in which it can be mitigated.

- If the vulnerability is caused as a result of an operation on a user-controlled ZIP archive, make sure that the archive does not contain a file that starts with `//`. Do this before calling `Path` on the `ZipFile` instance. For example:
```
zf = ZipFile("./user-controlled.zip", "r")
if any([i.startswith("//") for i in zf.namelist()]):
	raise ...
p = Path(zf)
...
```
- If the vulnerability is caused by a user-controlled filename in a new ZIP archive (e.g. `zf.writestr(user_input, "content")`), sanitize the filename and make sure it doesn't start with `//`.

krb5: GSS message token handling

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient input validation in Kerberos 5 may lead to denial of service when parsing message tokens with invalid length fields.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The `krb5` library is an implementation of the Kerberos Version 5 protocol, which is a widely used authentication protocol that provides secure authentication over insecure networks. The library contains the tools, APIs, and utilities necessary for applications and systems to integrate Kerberos for authentication and secure communication.

`GSS` tokens are part of the `Generic Security Services Application Program Interface` (GSS-API) used to provide secure communication between applications. A GSS token is essentially a chunk of data that encapsulates security information required for authentication, integrity, and confidentiality during Kerberos communication.

In MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5), an attacker can cause invalid memory reads during GSS message token handling by sending message tokens with invalid length fields, thus leading to denial of service.

The general structure of a wrap token contains a header, which includes fields such as `Extra Count`, and an encrypted part which includes the message.

For example, the vulnerability can be exploited in the following cases:

* A wrap token with a 0 value for the `Extra Count` field, which is the header value for padding.
* A wrap token with no header

Note:
This attack rely heavily on the attacker ability to MiTM.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to intercept the communication between the application and the server.

severityReasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to intercept the communication between the application and the server.

vulnerabilities.summary: krb5: GSS message token handling

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in Kerberos 5 may lead to an authentication bypass when parsing crafted GSS wrap tokens.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The `krb5` library is an implementation of the `Kerberos` Version 5 protocol, which is a widely used authentication protocol that provides secure authentication over insecure networks. The library contains the tools, APIs, and utilities necessary for applications and systems to integrate Kerberos for authentication and secure communication.

`GSS tokens` are part of the Generic Security Services Application Program Interface (GSS-API) used to provide secure communication between applications. A `GSS wrap token` is essentially a chunk of data that encapsulates encrypted data required for authentication, integrity, and confidentiality during Kerberos communication.

In MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5), attackers can craft the plaintext `Extra Count` field of a confidential GSS krb5 wrap token, causing the unwrapped token to appear truncated to the application.
In a truncation attack, the attacker somehow craft the message to indicate the message has finished in a way that will prevent the recipient picking up the rest of the message. This kind of attacks may lead to authentication bypass but rely heavily on the attacker ability to MiTM.

The general structure of a wrap token contains a header which includes the `Extra Count` field and an encrypted part which includes the message.
A wrap token with a different value of `Extra Count` field between the plaintext and encrypted copies will be erroneously accepted, which allows a message truncation attack.

The wrap token header structure is similar to:
```
TOK_ID      : 2 byte
Flags       : 1 byte
Filler      : 1 byte
Extra Count : 2 byte
RRC         : 2 byte
// Data (Encrypted)
```

To successfully exploit this vulnerability the attacker will have to override the RRC field and the encrypted data in a way which will cause the receiving application think it got all of the message. This may lead to several issues, from authentication bypass to DoS.

severityReasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to intercept the communication between the application and the server (performing a man-in-the-middle attack) and be able to modify the token.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Can lead to an authentication bypass.

vulnerabilities.summary: urllib3: proxy-authorization request header is not stripped during cross-origin redirects

urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python. When using urllib3's proxy support with `ProxyManager`, the `Proxy-Authorization` header is only sent to the configured proxy, as expected. However, when sending HTTP requests *without* using urllib3's proxy support, it's possible to accidentally configure the `Proxy-Authorization` header even though it won't have any effect as the request is not using a forwarding proxy or a tunneling proxy. In those cases, urllib3 doesn't treat the `Proxy-Authorization` HTTP header as one carrying authentication material and thus doesn't strip the header on cross-origin redirects. Because this is a highly unlikely scenario, we believe the severity of this vulnerability is low for almost all users. Out of an abundance of caution urllib3 will automatically strip the `Proxy-Authorization` header during cross-origin redirects to avoid the small chance that users are doing this on accident. Users should use urllib3's proxy support or disable automatic redirects to achieve safe processing of the `Proxy-Authorization` header, but we still decided to strip the header by default in order to further protect users who aren't using the correct approach. We believe the number of usages affected by this advisory is low. It requires all of the following to be true to be exploited: 1. Setting the `Proxy-Authorization` header without using urllib3's built-in proxy support. 2. Not disabling HTTP redirects. 3. Either not using an HTTPS origin server or for the proxy or target origin to redirect to a malicious origin. Users are advised to update to either version 1.26.19 or version 2.2.2. Users unable to upgrade may use the `Proxy-Authorization` header with urllib3's `ProxyManager`, disable HTTP redirects using `redirects=False` when sending requests, or not user the `Proxy-Authorization` header as mitigations.
requests: subsequent requests to the same host ignore cert verification

Requests is a HTTP library. Prior to 2.32.0, when making requests through a Requests `Session`, if the first request is made with `verify=False` to disable cert verification, all subsequent requests to the same host will continue to ignore cert verification regardless of changes to the value of `verify`. This behavior will continue for the lifecycle of the connection in the connection pool. This vulnerability is fixed in 2.32.0.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A null pointer dereference in the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) in the GNU C library may lead to denial of service.

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: No PoC and no technical writeup were published.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The `/etc/nscd.conf` configuration file does not support netgroup caching by default.

severityReasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
severityReasons.description: The Name Service Cache Daemon accepts arbitrary network input

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Disable netgroup caching in the NSCD configuration.
Remove the following line from `/etc/nscd.conf` -
```
enable-cache netgroup yes
```

vulnerabilities.summary: python-idna: potential DoS via resource consumption via specially crafted inputs to idna.encode()

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in idna may lead to denial of service when encoding crafted input.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[idna](https://github.com/kjd/idna) is a library used for encoding and decoding domain names according to the [IDNA](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5891) standard. This standard specifies how the conversion between domain names written in non-ASCII characters and their ASCII-based representation should be performed.

A vulnerability has been discovered in the function `valid_contextj()` in idna, which is responsible for validating certain rules that are related to [CONTEXTJ characters](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#autoid-32) ([`\u200c`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#appendix-A.1) and [`\u200d`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5892#appendix-A.2)). Specifically, the character `\u200c` requires a certain pattern to exist before and after the character. It has been discovered that the code in `valid_contextj()` keeps looking for the pattern even after it can no longer exist. This can lead to a denial of service attack, when the function is supplied with a very long input that contains a lot of `\u200c`.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability has a simple published exploit.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The impact of the vulnerability is a remote denial of service that requires no user interaction or per-target specific research.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: An attacker needs to find input that propagates to the vulnerable function `idna.encode()`.

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

There are two ways to mitigate this:
By limiting the input to 253 characters or not allowing for the character `\u200c` to exist in the input to the vulnerable function.

vulnerabilities.summary: nghttp2: CONTINUATION frames DoS

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in the implementation of the HTTP/2 protocol in Nghttp2 may lead to denial of service by abusing frame flags.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Nghttp2](https://github.com/nghttp2/nghttp2) is an open-source implementation of HTTP/2, a significant upgrade to the HTTP protocol, offering improved efficiency and performance for web communication. It provides libraries and command-line tools for developers to integrate HTTP/2 features into their applications, including binary framing, header compression, multiplexing of requests, and server push. `Nghttp2` is widely used in various projects, such as web servers, proxies, and clients.

`HTTP/2` is a binary protocol where the client and server exchange binary frames instead of text lines as in `HTTP/1.x`. `HTTP/2` resolves numerous concerns found in HTTP/1.1 by organizing each HTTP message into a series of HTTP/2 frames. These frames include frame type, length, flags, stream identifier (ID), and payload.

The `HEADERS` frame type allows sending HTTP headers of, both, request and response. The `HEADERS` frame contains many flags.
The `CONTINUATION` frame type is similar to the `HEADER` frame, but it has just one flag: `END_HEADERS`. When it is not set, the peer knows that more headers are coming in the following `CONTINUATION` frames.

This mechanism allows an attacker to send an `HTTP/2` stream with `CONTINUATION` frames, without setting the `END_HEADERS` flag in any of the frames. This can cause denial-of-service when sending an excessive number of these crafted frames due to caching all frames in memory.

The issue is exploitable by default due to `Nghttp2` being an `HTTP/2`-only implementation.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
severityReasons.description: Nghttp2 is vulnerable in its default configuration.

severityReasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
severityReasons.description: A very detailed technical write-up has been published regarding the issue.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: This issue can lead to denial of service.

severityReasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue has multiple mentions in general media
severityReasons.description: This issue is related to the well-covered attack "HTTP/2 CONTINUATION Flood".

urllib3: Request body not stripped after redirect from 303 status changes request method to GET

urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python. urllib3 previously wouldn't remove the HTTP request body when an HTTP redirect response using status 301, 302, or 303 after the request had its method changed from one that could accept a request body (like `POST`) to `GET` as is required by HTTP RFCs. Although this behavior is not specified in the section for redirects, it can be inferred by piecing together information from different sections and we have observed the behavior in other major HTTP client implementations like curl and web browsers. Because the vulnerability requires a previously trusted service to become compromised in order to have an impact on confidentiality we believe the exploitability of this vulnerability is low. Additionally, many users aren't putting sensitive data in HTTP request bodies, if this is the case then this vulnerability isn't exploitable. Both of the following conditions must be true to be affected by this vulnerability: 1. Using urllib3 and submitting sensitive information in the HTTP request body (such as form data or JSON) and 2. The origin service is compromised and starts redirecting using 301, 302, or 303 to a malicious peer or the redirected-to service becomes compromised. This issue has been addressed in versions 1.26.18 and 2.0.7 and users are advised to update to resolve this issue. Users unable to update should disable redirects for services that aren't expecting to respond with redirects with `redirects=False` and disable automatic redirects with `redirects=False` and handle 301, 302, and 303 redirects manually by stripping the HTTP request body.
libarchive: Race condition in multi-threaded use of archive_write_disk_header() on posix based systems

Requests is a HTTP library. Since Requests 2.3.0, Requests has been leaking Proxy-Authorization headers to destination servers when redirected to an HTTPS endpoint. This is a product of how we use `rebuild_proxies` to reattach the `Proxy-Authorization` header to requests. For HTTP connections sent through the tunnel, the proxy will identify the header in the request itself and remove it prior to forwarding to the destination server. However when sent over HTTPS, the `Proxy-Authorization` header must be sent in the CONNECT request as the proxy has no visibility into the tunneled request. This results in Requests forwarding proxy credentials to the destination server unintentionally, allowing a malicious actor to potentially exfiltrate sensitive information. This issue has been patched in version 2.31.0.

Python Packaging Authority (PyPA) setuptools before 65.5.1 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via HTML in a crafted package or custom PackageIndex page. There is a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) in package_index.py.

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An inefficient regular expression in setuptools PackageIndex leads to denial of service when processing an attacker-controlled Python package.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[Setuptools](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/) is a package for managing Python packages and dependencies, including tools for building and distributing packages, as well as for discovering and managing 3rd party packages available on PyPI.

The `find_external_links` function in the `setuptools.package_index` module is used to find external links that are associated with a package available on the Python Package Index (PyPI). These external links are typically URLs to the package's homepage, documentation, source code repository, and other resources that are related to the package.

The most common scenario of triggering this issue is when running pip with the `--editable` flag. This will cause the vulnerable `find_external_links` function to be invoked

Example of manual usage of `find_external_links` -
```
from setuptools.package_index import PackageIndex
import requests

# Specify the URL of the package page on PyPI
url = 'https://pypi.org/project/requests'

# Use the requests library to retrieve the HTML content of the package page
response = requests.get(url)

# Create an instance of the PackageIndex class
index = PackageIndex()

# Use the find_external_links function to find external links for the package
links = index.find_external_links(url, response.text)

# Print the name and URL of each external link
for link_name, link_url in links:
    print(f'{link_name}: {link_url}')
```
This example will find and print all external links for a package.

To find a specific url, i.e. the tag containing the `rel=` property, the `find_external_links` function uses a Regular Expression (regex). The regex is too not efficient which can lead to ReDoS on specific user inputs.
As a result, a user fetching malicious HTML from a package in PyPI or a custom PackageIndex page may be attacked.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: In cases where an attacker can already modify (or fully control) a package, then the attacker can change the package's code and immediately achieve arbitrary code execution. Since exploitation of this vulnerability has virtually the same prerequisites and only achieves DoS, this issue has a very low security impact

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: In most cases, exploiting the vulnerability will require user interaction (ex. running pip)

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description:
The attackers must be able to change package's content to add its malicious crafted `rel` property.
Moreover, any reviewer of the package's code will probably detect this and it will probably be caught by the lint and failed the usual lint process.
Also, the system installing the Python packages must use the `--editable` pip flag to trigger this vulnerability.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: Exploiting this vulnerability is easy, as it only depends on the number of spaces between the `rel` property and the `=` symbol and between the `=` symbol to the property's value.

vulnerabilities.summary: jquery: Untrusted code execution via <option> tag in HTML passed to DOM manipulation methods

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A design problem in jQuery allows network attackers to cause JavaScript code injection (XSS) by sending crafted HTML inputs.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[jQuery](https://jquery.com/) is an open-source JavaScript library meant to make many features of the language easier to use with simplified syntax. Because jQuery is widely imported and used in a large variety of software, its vulnerabilities affect numerous other components.

The `$.htmlPrefilter()` method is vulnerable to script injection due to a bug in a regex that replaces self-closing tags (`<tag />`) to full tags (`<tag ></tag>`) in the given HTML string

This string could arrive from untrusted input, such as user or network input. The [$.htmlPrefilter](https://api.jquery.com/jQuery.htmlPrefilter/) method isn't usually directly called by the frontend application developer that is using jQuery but indirectly by calling other common jQuery methods that internally call the `$.htmlPrefilter()` method, with the common ones being `$.html()`, `$.append()` and `$('<tag>')`. 

Thus, the vulnerability will usually be triggered by calling `$.html()` , `$.append()` and `$('<tag>')` with user input, since these methods call the underlying vulnerable method `$htmlPrefilter().` 

This vulnerability was discovered together with [CVE-2020-11022](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-11022), a different vulnerability in `$.htmlPrefilter` method. Both were released as part of this [detailed research](https://mksben.l0.cm/2020/05/jquery3.5.0-xss.html) and fixed in jQuery version 3.5.0 as well. As a best practice to protect and raise the bar against XSS attacks, it is best to sanitize HTML by using a secure third party, such as the open-source [DOMPurify](https://github.com/cure53/DOMPurify).

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: XSS leads to remote code execution (in Node.js environments)

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: Public [exploit[(https://mksben.l0.cm/2020/05/jquery3.5.0-xss.html) demonstrates JS code execution

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: Exploitation can only occur when using jQuery's `html()`, `append()`, `$('<tag>')` or`$htmlPrefilter()` functions to parse user input

severityReasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
severityReasons.description: https://mksben.l0.cm/2020/05/jquery3.5.0-xss.html

jfrogResearchInformation.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

* Securely sanitize untrusted HTML with [DOMPurify](https://github.com/cure53/DOMPurify)

vulnerabilities.summary: bzip2: bzip2: Data integrity error when decompressing (with data integrity tests fail).

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An heap out-of-bounds write in bzip2 may lead to remote code execution when decompressing a malicious archive.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
Lack of input validation in the `bzip2` decompressor code will lead to an OOB heap write, when accessing the `selectorMtf` array with an unbounded index.
An attacker can exploit this issue by decompressing a bzip2 archive that contains many selectors (see [Bzip2 file format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bzip2))

The OOB write data is **not controlled** by the attacker, but rather the OOB write will write incremental 1-byte values into the heap memory, at fixed offsets (depending on size of the `EState` struct). This is nontrivial to exploit for remote code execution, and would require significant research for heap shaping.

severityReasons.name: The issue has no exploit published
The CVE has no published technical writeup
The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: Very limited control of the overflown buffer

glibc: Integer overflow in memalign leads to heap corruption

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Integer overflow in glibc leads to non-attacker-controlled heap memory corruption and denial of service when  memory alignment parameters are externally-controlled.
jfrogResearchInformation.details: [Glib](https://docs.gtk.org/glib/) is the low-level core library that forms the basis for projects such as GTK and GNOME. It provides data structure handling for C, portability wrappers, and interfaces for such runtime functionality as an event loop, threads, dynamic loading, and an object system.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The vulnerable function writes non-attacker-controlled data as part of the heap corruption, thus only allowing for denial of service and not arbitrary code execution.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: An attacker needs to find an application linked to the glibc library which is using one of the vulnerable functions (e.g. `posix_memalign()`) in a way that the alignment parameter can be user-controlled, allowing the attacker to trigger the integer overflow. However, the alignment parameter used by the functions is usually a hard-coded power of two.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: PoC in the published advisory demonstrates memory corruption and a crash on the server when the function `posix_memalign()` is called with an excessive value of `2^63`.

openssl: SSL_select_next_proto buffer overread

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Heap buffer overread in OpenSSL may lead to data leakage or denial of service when calling SSL_select_next_proto with empty parameters
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
OpenSSL is an open-source cryptographic library and toolset that provides a wide range of protocol supported and functions for secure communication, data encryption, digital certificates, and other cryptographic operations, widely used in various software applications and systems.
Calling the OpenSSL API function SSL_select_next_proto with an empty supported client protocols buffer may cause a crash or memory contents to be sent to the peer. This vulnerability has a very low security impact, since this scenario is never valid, and cannot be influenced by attackers.

In order to be vulnerable, the vulnerable application must perform the aforementioned call and in addition needs to use the legacy NPN callback.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: This issue only affects applications that explicitly invoke the `SSL_select_next_proto` function with an empty list of supported client protocol and use NPN or ALPN where the 'no overlap' response in the ALPN is mishandled. Note that an attacker has no control over these conditions and they are not related to any network input.

cpython: python: Memory race condition in ssl.SSLContext certificate store methods

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Race condition in Python's ssl built-in module may result in denial of service when performing multi-threaded SSL operations.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[ssl](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html) is a CPython module that provides access to Transport Layer Security (TLS) encryption and peer authentication facilities for network sockets. This model uses the OpenSSL library.

A race condition vulnerability was found in the `ssl.SSLContext` methods `rt_store_stats()` and `get_ca_certs()` when they are called at the same time as certificates are loaded into the `SSLContext`. When the `cert_store_stats()` or `get_ca_certs()` methods are called on a separate thread from the one that initiates the TLS handshake. This, in turn, could lead to memory corruption when the methods attempt to read the certificates prematurely, potentially resulting in the freeing of the `SSLContext` internal certificate store. When the thread responsible for the certificate loading finishes its certificate loading operation, it attempts to continue working with the certificate store.

 However, because the store was freed due to the premature reading of it, the thread is now holding a reference to memory that has been deallocated. When it attempts to use the pointer, it will result in the crash of the Python interpreter, resulting in a denial of service.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Race condition leading to a crash due to use after free.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: An attacker cannot control whether the vulnerability is triggered. The vulnerability is only triggered when the application uses multiple threads to interact with SSLContext during certificate loading, which is an uncommon pattern in typical applications.

openssl: Use After Free with SSL_free_buffers

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A use after free in OpenSSL may lead to denial of service or code execution when calling SSL_free_buffers in specific time-dependent scenarios.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
OpenSSL is an open-source cryptographic library and toolset that provides a wide range of protocol supported and functions for secure communication, data encryption, digital certificates, and other cryptographic operations, widely used in various software applications and systems.
When processing an incoming record from the network, OpenSSL makes use of an internal buffer to save the incoming encrypted data. The function `SSL_free_buffers` is an API function that frees this internal buffer, in case a user wants to have more control over the SSL object in use.

Calls to `SSL_free_buffers` are supposed to fail for buffers that are actively in use. However, two situations were found in which the call succeeds even though the buffer is in use, leading to a use after free which attackers could potentially leverage into a denial of service, corruption of data or remote code execution.

The first scenario occurs where a record header has been received, but the full record body has not yet arrived.
In this case calling `SSL_free_buffers` will succeed even though OpenSSL will internally continue to use the buffer.

The second scenario occurs where a full record has been received but the application has only read part of this data. The call to `SSL_free_buffers` will succeed again, even though OpenSSL will internally continue to use the buffer.

severityReasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
severityReasons.description: Impact ranges from denial of service to code execution, depending on the code of the vulnerable application.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: Only applications that directly call `SSL_free_buffers` are affected

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: Exploitation requires engineering very specific, unlikely scenarios and require substantial per-target research from the attacker.

libxml2: buffer over-read in xmlHTMLPrintFileContext in xmllint.c

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: A heap buffer underread in libxml2's xmllint utility may lead to denial of service when parsing crafted files under a specific configuration
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
`xmllint` is a CLI tool that comes with the libxml2 library, commonly used for parsing, validating, and formatting XML documents. It allows users to check whether an XML file is well-formed or valid against a specified DTD or XML Schema.

A heap buffer overread in `xmllint` may lead to denial of service when a crafted file is being given as input to the `xmllint` CLI tool and the `--htmlout` flag is used.
For example -
```
xmllint --htmlout crafted_input
```

The `xmlHTMLPrintFileContext` function of `xmllint.c` is responsible for formatting and displaying error messages when the `--htmlout` flag is used.

The function attempts to strip trailing newline or carriage return characters (\n or \r) from the file content context buffer by decrementing a pointer (cur) in a loop:

```
while ((*cur == '\n') || (*cur == '\r')) cur--;
```

The issue is that this loop lacks a boundary check. If the file content buffer contains only newline characters (or ends with a long sequence of them), the pointer `cur` can be decremented past the beginning of the allocated buffer, resulting in a buffer under-read. This means the program reads memory that immediately precedes the intended buffer, which can lead to a crash.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: Public PoC demonstrates denial of service

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The CVE is applicable only when xmllint is being run with the `--htmlout` flag and a crafted file as input.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Crashing a forked CLI tool has no real-world security impact

glibc: netgroup cache assumes NSS callback uses in-buffer strings

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Out of bounds write in NSCD may lead to remote code execution when an attacker controls the response of an NSS module.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) is a process in Linux and Unix-like systems that caches name service lookups (like user, group, and hostname information) to reduce latency and system load on backend services such as NIS, LDAP, or DNS. By storing frequently accessed data, it speeds up identity and network resolution for client applications.

NSCD provides a stack buffer for NSS modules to store netgroup strings (user, host, domain names). The vulnerable code assumes that all resulting strings are stored as offsets within this provided buffer. If a malicious or misconfigured NSS module returns a netgroup entry where a string pointer points to an address outside of NSCD's buffer, NSCD still treats this absolute pointer as a relative offset from the cache buffer's base. When NSCD later processes the cached entry, this offset calculation may lead to an out-of-bound write, corrupting internal memory, which can be exploited by an attacker (who can control the NSS response) to achieve arbitrary code execution within the NSCD process.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description: The attacker needs a way to control the output of an NSS module that NSCD queries for netgroup lookups. This is typically achieved by setting a malicious network service (e.g. LDAP, NIS) or by exploiting an existing configuration that allows user-controlled inputs. Or by supplying a specially crafted netgroup entry that will be served by a controllable NSS source.

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: A stack out-of-bounds write has a high probability of leading to arbitrary code execution

severityReasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
severityReasons.description: The vulnerability is not a standard stack buffer overflow, and no technical information or PoC exploit have been supplied

vulnerabilities.summary: glibc: netgroup cache may terminate daemon on memory allocation failure

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Unhandled memory allocation failures in NSCD may lead to denial of service by network attackers when issuing an enormous amount of DNS requests
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) is a process in Linux and Unix-like systems that caches name service lookups (like user, group, and hostname information) to reduce latency and system load on backend services such as NIS, LDAP, or DNS. By storing frequently accessed data, it speeds up identity and network resolution for client applications.

When a client application (e.g., ssh, a login process) requests information about a netgroup, the NSCD Daemon tries to:

1. Look up the netgroup data from an external source (like NIS or LDAP).

2. Allocate a buffer of memory to store the retrieved data in its internal cache for future, faster lookups.

`xmalloc` and `xrealloc` are internal `glibc` helper functions designed for code where memory allocation failure is considered a fatal error that should never happen or can't be gracefully handled at that point. Unlike standard allocation functions, xmalloc and xrealloc are designed to forcefully terminate the process if they encounter a memory allocation failure.

NSCD was using `xmalloc` or `xrealloc` for its netgroup cache logic and therefore was exposed to denial of service whenever either of the functions failed.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
To successfully exploit this CVE, the attacker will have to either:

1. Cause resource exhaustion: repeatedly send lookup requests for a large volume of unique netgroup entries, forcing NSCD to continuously allocate new memory until the process's limits are reached and a subsequent allocation fails. 

2. Create an oversized entry: an attacker, who has control over the backend directory service (like NIS or LDAP), will have to configure a single, extremely large netgroup entry. A request for this entry forces NSCD to attempt one massive allocation that immediately fails due to insufficient memory, triggering the crash.

In addition, successfully executing the denial of service attack is dependent on the amount of memory the system has.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The attacker can simply send many name resolution requests

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description:
1. When crashed, the NSCD daemon will be restarted automatically on most Linux distros.
2. The amount of packets required to cause a crash varies on the amount of the memory the victim machine has, but in any real-world case would be extremely large, making the attack ineffective

vulnerabilities.summary: glibc: netgroup cache may terminate daemon on memory allocation failure

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Unhandled memory allocation failures in NSCD may lead to denial of service by network attackers when issuing an enormous amount of DNS requests
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) is a process in Linux and Unix-like systems that caches name service lookups (like user, group, and hostname information) to reduce latency and system load on backend services such as NIS, LDAP, or DNS. By storing frequently accessed data, it speeds up identity and network resolution for client applications.

When a client application (e.g., ssh, a login process) requests information about a netgroup, the NSCD Daemon tries to:

1. Look up the netgroup data from an external source (like NIS or LDAP).

2. Allocate a buffer of memory to store the retrieved data in its internal cache for future, faster lookups.

`xmalloc` and `xrealloc` are internal `glibc` helper functions designed for code where memory allocation failure is considered a fatal error that should never happen or can't be gracefully handled at that point. Unlike standard allocation functions, xmalloc and xrealloc are designed to forcefully terminate the process if they encounter a memory allocation failure.

NSCD was using `xmalloc` or `xrealloc` for its netgroup cache logic and therefore was exposed to denial of service whenever either of the functions failed.

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
To successfully exploit this CVE, the attacker will have to either:

1. Cause resource exhaustion: repeatedly send lookup requests for a large volume of unique netgroup entries, forcing NSCD to continuously allocate new memory until the process's limits are reached and a subsequent allocation fails. 

2. Create an oversized entry: an attacker, who has control over the backend directory service (like NIS or LDAP), will have to configure a single, extremely large netgroup entry. A request for this entry forces NSCD to attempt one massive allocation that immediately fails due to insufficient memory, triggering the crash.

In addition, successfully executing the denial of service attack is dependent on the amount of memory the system has.

severityReasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
severityReasons.description: The attacker can simply send many name resolution requests

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description:
1. When crashed, the NSCD daemon will be restarted automatically on most Linux distros.
2. The amount of packets required to cause a crash varies on the amount of the memory the victim machine has, but in any real-world case would be extremely large, making the attack ineffective

ncurses: segfaulting OOB read

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: An out-of-bounds read in ncurses terminfo leads to memory leakage.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[ncurses](https://invisible-mirror.net/archives/ncurses/) (new curses) is a programming library providing an application programming interface (API) that allows the programmer to write text-based user interfaces (TUI) in a terminal-independent manner. It is a toolkit for developing "GUI-like" application software that runs under a terminal emulator.

The `convert_strings` function in the `terminfo` module of `ncurses` is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read, leading to memory leakage. The bug is triggerable by means of the `/progs/tic` tool that ships with ncurses and compiles a terminfo source. An example of running the tic tool - 
```
/progs/tic -o /path/to/output/directory/ <TIC_SOURCE_FILEPATH>
```
The vulnerability can be triggered when the attacker controls the contents of the TIC_SOURCE file.

The [PoC](https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-ncurses/2022-04/msg00014.html) published is a terminfo file with special characters and Unicode characters leading to a memory leakage and a crash when reading a bad address. It is hardly usable by an attacker as the leaked memory either causes a crash - and so the data leaked is not obtainable - or written to a local output file, which doesn't benefit remote attackers.

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: Either leads to a client program DoS or to a memory leak into a local file.

severityReasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
severityReasons.description:
Remote exploitation is unlikely to happen or to be beneficial for the attacker.

The attacker should be able to control the contents of the terminfo source file, when the `tic` command is run -
`/progs/tic -o /path/to/output/directory/ <TIC_SOURCE_FILEPATH>`

In addition, the attacker must find a way to get the output file with the leaked memory information, which is very unlikely to happen.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: A PoC has been published to reproduce the bug to leak memory contents.

vulnerabilities.summary: tar: does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Preserving SETUID/SETGID bits when extracting with tar may lead to privilege escalation.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
When running as the "root" user, tar will restore by default the original permissions to any extracted files (this can be controlled via the `-p` argument). One of the restored permission bits are the SETUID/SETGID bits which make the extracted executable automatically elevate to "root" privileges, regardless of the user that ran the executable.

This behavior could be an issue when the root user extracts a crafted tar archive, which contains a SUID-enabled malicious executable, that allows privilege escalation.
De-facto, this behavior is widely known, documented and accepted behavior, and as such this issue did not receive a fix.

severityReasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
severityReasons.description: A root user must extract the "affected" tar archive

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description: The attacker must find a vulnerability in the extracted SETUID program in order to run arbitrary code, or alternatively make the root user extract an attacker-crafted tar archive

severityReasons.name: The issue cannot be exploited on its own, and can only be used as part of an attack chain
severityReasons.description: Simply preserving the SETUID/SETGID bits will not lead to privilege escalation. The extracted program must still have a vulnerability that will allow the unprivileged user to achieve arbitrary (local) code execution

severityReasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
severityReasons.description: Both Red Hat and Debian security trackers disputed the issue, citing "This is the documented and expected behaviour of tar."

vulnerabilities.summary: python-pip: Incorrect handling of unicode separators in git references

jfrogResearchInformation.summary: Insufficient tag filtering in pip allows highly-privileged attackers to hijack git repository tags.
jfrogResearchInformation.details:
[pip](https://pypi.org/project/pip) is the package installer for Python. You can use pip to install packages from the Python Package Index and other indexes.
It was discovered that `pip` used Unicode whitespace characters as path separators, although these characters are allowed to be a part of a git tag.
Specifically, if the victim would install a pip module via a git URL - ex. `pip install git+https://github.com/foo/bar.git@some_tag` and the attacker can push a new tag to `https://github.com/foo/bar.git` (with an arbitrary name), the attacker would be able to hijack `some_tag` by pushing a completely new tag with a name similar to `some_tag` but with Unicode whitespace characters. Due to a fault in `pip`, this would make the victim pull the attacker's malicious version of `some_tag` instead of the original intended version.

severityReasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
severityReasons.description: Exploit demonstrates git tag hijacking

severityReasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
severityReasons.description: The attack would cause the victim to install an attacker-controlled version of the pip module instead of the intended version, leading directly to arbitrary code execution in most cases

severityReasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
severityReasons.description:
The victim must use `pip` to install a module with a specific tag name, from a repository that an attacker can push new (other) git tags to.
For example - `pip install git+https://github.com/foo/bar.git@some_tag`

severityReasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
severityReasons.description: The attacker must be able to push new git tags to the targeted repository. This severely lowers the security impact of this attack since in most cases this means the attacker has completely control of the git repository anyways.
